title: John Stanhope: Why Ahmed Fahour is a target
text:
The consumer finance group's float, expected to be the year's biggest IPO, was pulled on Tuesday by owners KKR, Deutsche Bank and Varde Partners after failing to drum up sufficient interest from investors at $1.78 a share.

Mr Stanhope's comments came as Merlon Capital Partners' portfolio manager Hamish Carlisle said the big question was whether Mr Fahour would stay at Latitude and prove his credentials as a chief executive.

"Whether he was there [at Latitude] as an agent alongside the underwriters to sell the business, or whether he was there because of his skills as a CEO will ultimately be answered when we see if he is there in a year or so," he said.

"Whether you regard his role as an agent of the shareholders to sell the business, or run the business for new shareholders became quite blurred with the context of the financial alignment."

Selling himself

Mr Stanhope added that Mr Fahour's strengths included selling himself.

"Part of Ahmed's background and capability is that he's pretty much a good sales guy and he sells himself very well ... he genuinely believes he's worth the value he demands.

"The open question is [whether he is] worth what he'd like to be paid? At the end of the day, the people who decide to employ him have to make that judgement."

Mr Stanhope said Mr Fahour curbed losses at Australia Post during his time as chief executive.

Mr Carlisle added that his fund preferred companies to appoint chief executives from within the organistion, rather than draft in external, high-profile talent.

"The fly in, fly out celebrity CEO has generally not proven to be a long term source of value creation for companies," he said.
description: Australia Post chairman John Stanhope has defended the legacy of Ahmed Fahour at the government-owned logistics group.
